label: Bitcoin consumes roughly 1 percent of the world’s energy consumption. What does this mean about its security?

choices.value: Bitcoin is secure to the point that it would require approximately 1% of the entire world’s energy consumption to attack the network.
Bitcoin is secure to the point that it would require approximately 0 .0001% of the entire world’s energy consumption to attack the network.
A malicious actor would need 10 times the amount of Bitcoin’s energy consumption in order to successfully attack the network.
A malicious actor doesn’t need to consider the total energy consumption in order to successfully execute a 51% attack.
An older method of confirming bitcoin transactions now replaced by single-sig verification
Verification that a user is allowed to hold bitcoins in a certain address by requiring multiple signatures from friends and family
A process by which miners select which transaction to verify by having three other miners create a signature giving permission for the transaction to be verified
A technology to verify wallets by requiring multiple signatures to process a single transaction with enhanced security
Another name for a node
An empty value in each block that is filled by the miner of that block
A part inside a processing chip used in mining
A mining device faster than an ASIC

label: What is a Merkle Root in Bitcoin?

choices.value: A part of a complex system of underground “roots” that power the Bitcoin blockchain
A series of complex data that uniquely identifies the owner of an address
A program designed by David Merkle that uncovers the largest inactive bitcoin wallets
A hash of all transactions in a block that allows any specific transaction to be verified without downloading the entire blockchain
